Extracted from ≈øeveral Authors, in order to ≈øhew the Iniquity of that TRADE, and the Fal≈øity of the ARGUMENTS u≈øually advanced in its Vindication. With a Quotation from GEORGE WALLIS'S Sy≈øtem of the Laws, &c. and a large Extract from a Pamphlet, lately publi≈øhed in London, on the Subject of the SLAVE TRADE.

q.p: GOD that made the World‚Äîhath made of one Blood all Nations of Men, for to dwell on all the Face of the Earth, and hath determined the Times before appointed, and the Bounds of their Habitation.
The People of the Land have u≈øed Oppre≈øpre≈øion, and exerci≈øed Robbery, and have vexed the Poor and Needy; yea, they have oppre≈ø≈øed the Stranger wrongfully.

div.head: A SHORT ACCOUNT OF THE Slave-Trade, &c.
div.p:
IT is a Truth, as ≈øorrowful as obvious, that Mankind too generally are actuated by fal≈øe Motives, and ≈øub≈øtitute an imaginary Intere≈øt in the Room of that which is real and permanent: And it mu≈øt be acknowledged by every Man, who is ≈øincerely de≈øirous of becoming acquainted with him≈øelf, and impartially in≈øpects his own Heart, that Weakne≈øs and inbred Corruption attends human Nature; which cannot be re≈øtored to its original Purity, but through the Efficacy of the Blood of JESUS CHRIST, our ble≈ø≈øed Saviour. So that notwith≈øtanding the imagined moral Rectitude pleaded for, and the boa≈øted Pretences of the pre≈øent Age to refined Conceptions of Things beyond our Forefathers, all this Divine Help is embraced, the bent of the Heart of Man will remain corrupt, and its Power of di≈øtingui≈øhing between Good and Evil liable to be ob≈øcured by Prejudice, Pa≈ø≈øion and
Intere≈øt. Covetou≈øne≈øs and Pride have introduced many iniquitous Practices into Civil Society, ≈øome of which being e≈øtabli≈øhed by Cu≈øtom, and adapted to flatter our Favourite Pa≈ø≈øions, tho' odious in them≈øelves, and mo≈øt pernicious in their Con≈øequences, yet, through the Influence of Example and U≈øe, become familiar to us, and our depraved Rea≈øon has Recour≈øe to plau≈øible Excu≈øes, to cover and palliate the mo≈øt atrocious Crimes; ≈øo that by Degrees we ≈øilence the Dictates of Con≈øcience, and reconcile our≈øelves in the Perpetration of ≈øuch Things which, when fir≈øt propo≈øed to our unprejudiced Minds, would ≈øtrike us with Amazement and Horror.

A lamentable and ≈øhocking In≈øtance of the Influence which the Love of Gain has upon the Minds of tho≈øe who yield to its Allurements, even when contrary to the Dictates of Rea≈øon, and the common Feelings of Humanity, appears in the Pro≈øecution of the Negroe Trade, in which the Engli≈øh Nation has long been deeply concerned, and ≈øome in this Province have al≈øo lately engaged. An Evil of ≈øo deep a Dye, and attended with ≈øuch dreadful Con≈øequences to all that are concerned in it, that no well-di≈øpo≈øed Per≈øon, anxious for the Welfare of him≈øelf, his Country, or Po≈øterity, who knows the Tyranny, Oppre≈ø≈øion and Cruelty with which this iniquitous Trade is carried on, can be a ≈øilent and innocent Spectator. How many Thou≈øands of our harmle≈øs Fellow Creatures have, for a long Cour≈øe of Years, fallen a Sacrifice to that ≈øelfi≈øh Avarice, which gives Life to this complicated Wickedne≈øs.
The Iniquity of being ≈øo deeply engaged in a Trade, by which ≈øo great a Number of innocent People are yearly de≈øtroyed, in ≈øo untimely and mi≈øerable a Manner, is greatly aggravated from the Con≈øideration that we, as a Nation, have been peculiarly favoured with the bright Beams of the Go≈øpel; that Revelation of Divine Love, which the Angels introduced to the World, by a Declaration of Peace on Earth, and Good Will to Men‚Äîof every Nation, Kindred, Tongue and People. How mi≈øerable then mu≈øt be our Condition, if, for filthy Lucre, we ≈øhould continue to act ≈øo contrary to the Nature of this Divine Call, the Purpo≈øe of which is to introduce an univer≈øal and affectionate Brotherhood in the whole human Species; by removing from the Heart of every Individual, who ≈øubmits to its Operation, the Darkne≈øs and Corruption of Nature, and transforming the ≈øelfi≈øh, wrathful, proud Spirit, into Meekne≈øs, Purity and Love: For this End the Son of GOD became Man, ≈øuffered, and died; and the whole Tenor of the Go≈øpel declares, that for tho≈øe who refu≈øe, or neglect, the Offers of this great Salvation, the Son of GOD has ≈øuffered in vain.

The End propo≈øed by this E≈ø≈øay, is to lay before the candid Reader the Depth of Evil which attends this iniquitous Practice, in the Pro≈øecution of which, our Duty to GOD, the common Father of the Family of the whole Earth, and our Duty of Love to our Fellow Creatures, is totally di≈øregarded; all ≈øocial Connection and tender Ties of Nature being broken, and De≈øolation
and Blood≈øhed continually fomented in tho≈øe unhappy People's Country. It is al≈øo intended to invalidate ≈øome fal≈øe Arguments, which are frequently advanced, for the Palliation thereof, in Hopes it may be ≈øome Inducement to tho≈øe who are not defiled with this Trade, to keep them≈øelves clear; and to lay before ≈øuch as have unwarily engaged in it, the Danger they are in of totally lo≈øing that tender Sen≈øibility to the Sufferings of their Fellow Creatures, the Want whereof ≈øets Men beneath the Brute Creation, which mu≈øt unavoidably be the State of every one that continues to partake of the Profits ari≈øing from this wicked Traffick: A Trade by which ≈øo many Thou≈øands of innocent People are brought under the greate≈øt Anxiety and Suffering, being violently rent from their Native Country, in the mo≈øt cruel Manner, and brought to our Colonies, to be employed in hard Labour, either in Northern Climates, un≈øuited to their Nature, or in a State of the mo≈øt tyrannick and barbarous Slavery, ≈øubject to the Humours and inhuman La≈øh of ≈øome of the mo≈øt hard hearted and incon≈øiderate of Mankind, without any Hopes of ever returning to their Native Land, or ≈øeeing an End to their Mi≈øery: Nor mu≈øt we omit, in this di≈ømal Account, the Weight of Blood which lies on the Promoters of this Trade, from the great Numbers that are yearly butchered in the Incur≈øions and Battles which happen between the Negroes, in order to procure the Number delivered to the Europeans; and the many of the≈øe poor Creatures who≈øe Hearts are broken, and
who peri≈øh, through Mi≈øery and Grief, on the Pa≈ø≈øage. Heaven pre≈øerve the Inhabitants of Penn≈øylvania from being further defiled by a Trade, which is entered upon from ≈øuch ≈øen≈øual Motives, and carried on by ≈øuch devili≈øh Means. And although the≈øe Scenes of Horror are acted in Places far remote, and out of the Sight of tho≈øe who are the mo≈øt enriched thereby; who≈øe Sen≈øes being u≈øually exerci≈øed only by pre≈øent Objects, are little affected with the di≈øtant Sufferings of their Fellow Creatures; yet every Mind, which is not ≈øo hardened with the Love of Wealth as to be void of feeling, mu≈øt, upon ≈øerious Con≈øideration of this inhuman Practice, be impre≈ø≈øed with Surprize and Terror, from a Sen≈øe that there is a righteous GOD, and a State of Retribution, which mu≈øt la≈øt for ever. It is frequently alledged, in Excu≈øe for this Trade, that the Negroes ≈øold in our Plantations, are mo≈øtly Per≈øons who have been taken Pri≈øoners in tho≈øe Wars which ari≈øe among≈øt them≈øelves, from their mutual Animo≈øities; and that the≈øe Pri≈øoners would be ≈øacrificed, to the Re≈øentment of tho≈øe who have taken them Captives. If they were not purcha≈øed and brought away by the Europeans. It is al≈øo repre≈øented, that the Negroes are generally a ≈øtupid ≈øavage People, who≈øe Situation in their own Country is nece≈ø≈øitous and unhappy, which has induced many to believe, that the bringing the Africans from their Native Land is to them rather a Kindne≈øs than an Injury.

To confute the≈øe fal≈øe Repre≈øentations, the following Extracts are propo≈øed to the candid
Reader's Con≈øideration; they are taken from the Writings of the principal Officers, not only in the Engli≈øh, but al≈øo in the French and Dutch Factories or Settlements in Guiney, ≈øome of whom have lived many Years in tho≈øe Countries, and have been Eye Witne≈ø≈øes to tho≈øe Tran≈øactions, and who≈øe Station in the Factories will not admit of any Doubt of the Truth of what they relate; by which it will appear, that the Negroes are generally ≈øen≈øible, humane and ≈øociable, and that their Capacity is as good, and as capable of Improvement, as that of the White People: That their Country, though unfriendly to the Europeans, yet appears peculiarly agreeable, and well adapted to the Nature of the Blacks, and ≈øo fruitful, as to furni≈øh its Inhabitants plentifully with the Nece≈ø≈øaries of Life, with much le≈øs Labour than is nece≈ø≈øary in our more Northern Countries. And as to the common Argument, alledged in Defence of the Trade, viz. That the Slaves ≈øold to the Europeans are Captives taken in War, who would be de≈øtroyed by their Conquerors, if not thus purcha≈øed, it is without Foundation, it being made clearly to appear, from the forementioned Te≈øtimonies, that the Wars and Incur≈øions made by the Negroes, one upon another, are mo≈øtly at the Solicitation of the Europeans, who in≈øtigate them by every Method, even the mo≈øt iniquitous and cruel, to procure Slaves to load their Ve≈ø≈øels, which they freely purcha≈øe, without any Regard to the Precepts of the Go≈øpel, the feelings of Humanity, or the common Dictates of Rea≈øon and Equity.
For though it is ≈øcare to be doubted, but that there were Wars among≈øt ≈øome of the Negroes, before the Europeans began to trade with them, yet certain it is, that the≈øe Calamities are not only ≈øince that Time prodigiou≈øly encrea≈øed, and the Europeans, by encouraging them thereto, and gladly purcha≈øing the Captives they take, are become come not only Parties with them therein, but the ≈øole Cau≈øe of that Encrea≈øe. This is plainly inferred from the Account given by N. Brue, Director of the French Factory at Senegal, who lived Twenty-≈øeven Years in that Country, who ≈øays, That the Europeans are far from de≈øiring to act as Peace Makers among≈øt the Negroes, which would be acting contrary to their Intere≈øt, ≈øince the greater the Wars, the more Slaves are procured.

William Bo≈øman, Factor for the Dutch, at Delmina, where he re≈øided ≈øixteen Years, relates, That one of the former Commanders hired an Army of the Negroes, of Jafferia and Cabe≈øteria, for a large Sum of Money, to fight the Negroes of Commany, which occa≈øioned a Battle, which was more bloody than the Wars of the Negroes u≈øually are: And that another Commander gave, at one time, Five Hundrea Pounds, and at another time Eight Hundred Pounds, to two other Negroe Nations, to induce them to take up Arms again≈øt their Country People. This is confirmed by Barbot, Agent General of the French African Company, who ≈øays; The Hollanders, a People very zealous for their Commerce at the Coa≈øt, were very
≈øtudious to have the War carried on among≈øt the Blacks, to di≈øtract, as long as po≈ø≈øible, the Trade of the other Europeans; and to that Effect were very ready to a≈ø≈øi≈øt upon all Occa≈øions the Blacks, their Allies, that they might beat their Enemies, and ≈øo the Commerce fall into their Hands. But nothing ≈øhews more plainly, that the Europeans are the chief In≈øtruments in inciting the Negroes to the Perpetration of tho≈øe unnatural Wars, by which they are kept in continual Alarms, their Country laid wa≈øte, and ≈øuch great Numbers carried into Captivity, than the Account given by William Smith, who was ≈øent by the African Company to vi≈øit their Settlements in the Year 1726, from the Information he received of one of the Factors, who had re≈øided ten Years in that Country, viz. That the di≈øcerning Natives account it their greate≈øt Unhappine≈øs that they were ever vi≈øited by the Europeans:‚ÄîThat we Chri≈øtians introduced the Traffick of Slaves, and that before our coming they lived in Peace; but, ≈øay they, it is ob≈øervable, that wherever Chri≈øtianity comes, there comes with it a Sword, a Gun, Powder and Ball.

As to the Account of the natural Di≈øpo≈øition of many of the Negroes, and of the Fruitfulne≈øs of their Country, the forementioned Authors, as well as many others, have wrote largely upon it. M. Adan≈øon, in his Account of the Country and Natives of Goree, where he was ≈øo lately as the Year 1754, after giving an Account of the delightful A≈øpect of the Country, ≈øays; The Simplicity
of the Natives, their Dre≈øs and Manners, revived in my Mind the Idea of our fir≈øt Parents; and I ≈øeemed to contemplate the World in its primitive State;‚Äîthey (the Negroes) are generally ≈øpeaking, very good natured, ≈øociable and obliging. I was not a little plea≈øed (≈øays he) with this my fir≈øt Reception; ‚Äîit convinced me, that there ought to be a con≈øiderable Abatement made in the Accounts I had read and heard every where of the ≈øavage Character of the Africans.‚ÄîI ob≈øerved, both in Negroes and Moors, great Humanity and Sociablene≈øs, which gave me ≈øtrong Hopes that I ≈øhould be very ≈øafe among≈øt them, and meet with the Succe≈øs I de≈øired in my Enquiries after the Curio≈øities of the Country.

Bo≈øman, ≈øpeaking of the Negroes of that Part Guiney where he then was, ≈øays; They are generally a good Sort of People, hone≈øt in their Dealings; others he de≈øcribes as being generally friendly to Strangers, of a mild Conver≈øation, courteous, affable, and ea≈øy to be overcome with Rea≈øon; in Conver≈øation they di≈øcover a great Quickne≈øs of Parts and Under≈øtanding. He adds, That ≈øome Negroes, who have had an agreeable Education, have manife≈øted a Brightne≈øs of Under≈øtanding equal to any of us.

William Smith's Account of the Natives is, That he found them a civil good natured People, indu≈øtrious to the la≈øt Degree, and their Country exceeding Fertile.‚ÄîIt is ea≈øy
(≈øays he) to perceive what happy Memories they are ble≈ø≈øed with, and how great Progre≈øs they would make in the Sciences, in ca≈øe their Genius was cultivated with Study: They explain them≈øelves in choice Terms, their Expre≈ø≈øions noble, and Manners polite;‚Äîthis (he adds) is to be under≈øtood of the People of Di≈øtinction, as Officers, Merchantmen, and the like; for Pea≈øants, Workmen and Shepherds, are as ignorant in the≈øe Parts as el≈øewhere.

Barbot ≈øays, The Inhabitants of Oedo are, for the Generality, very civil, good natured People, ea≈øy to be dealt with, conde≈øcending to what the Europeans require of them, in a civil Way; but if treated with Haughtine≈øs and rudely, they are ≈øtiff and high, and will not yield on any Account.

Some Writers have repre≈øented the Natives of Cape Me≈øurado as faithle≈øs and cruel; but it is very likely this Repre≈øentation of their Di≈øpo≈øition was occa≈øioned by the Re≈øentment they had ≈øhewn for the ill U≈øage received from the Europeans; for Captain Philips declared them to be civil and courteous. And Snoek ≈øays, He found them a civil good-natur'd People; but that the late Injury they had received from the Engli≈øh, who had carried off ≈øome of their People, had ≈øo exa≈øperated them, that it was to be feared ≈øome Engli≈øh People they had in their Power, would fall a Sacrifice to their Re≈øentment.

Although the extream Heat in many Parts of Guiney, is ≈øuch as is neither agreeable nor healthy
to the Europeans, yet it is well ≈øuited to the Con≈øtitution of the Negroes: And it is to the≈øe Heats that they are indebted for the fertility of their Land, which in mo≈øt Places is ≈øo great, that with little Labour Grain and Fruit will grow in the greate≈øt Plenty.

Brue, in his Account of the Fertility of the Country, and Indu≈øtry of the Natives, ≈øays; He was ≈øurprized to ≈øee the Land ≈øo well cultivated, as he ob≈øerved it to be, in one of his Journies; ≈øcarce a Spot lay unimproved; the low Grounds, divided by ≈ømall Canals, were all ≈øowed with Rice; the higher Grounds planted with Indian Corn and Millet, and Pea≈øe of different Sorts, Beef and Mutton very cheap, as well as all other Nece≈ø≈øaries of Life.

Bo≈øman ≈øays, The Indian and Guiney Corn is here ≈øown and reaped twice every Year; the fir≈øt Harve≈øt is in Augu≈øt, and the other the latter End of the Year, though but ≈ømall, Corn grows with little Trouble, very ≈øpeedily taking Root, ≈øo that one or two Men can manure and plow as much Land as one Plow can turn up in Holland. Indian Corn grows in the upper Lands, in prodigious Quantities, and where Corn won't grow, there Rice encrea≈øes in Abundance, and Yamms and Potatoes are in the greate≈øt Plenty.

Speaking of the Kingdom of Fida, he ≈øays, The Country was very populous, many large Villages, be≈øides innumerable ≈ømall Ones, through the whole Country, plentifully provided with Corn, Potatoes and Fruit, which
grew clo≈øe to each other; in ≈øome Places a Foot Path is the only Ground that is not covered with them, the Negroes leaving no Place, which is thought fertile, uncultivated, even within the Hedges which inclo≈øe their Villages: And the very next Day after they have reaped they are ≈øure to ≈øow again. This ≈øine Country is now very much depopulated, which it is likely, was owing to the Incur≈øions made upon them by their Neighbours, in order to get Slaves to ≈øell to the Europeans. For the ≈øame Bo≈øman, ≈øpeaking of the neighbouring Nation of Pope, ≈øays; They depend on Plunder and the Slave Trade, in which they exceed ≈øome of their Neighbours.

Other Parts of the Country he de≈øcribes, as being full of Towns and Villages; the Soil very rich, and ≈øo well cultivated, as to look like and entire Garden, abounding in Rice, Corn, Oxen, Goats and Poultry; and the Negroes to be laborious.

W. Smith gives much the ≈øame Account of the Country of Delmina, and Cape Cor≈øe, &c. for Beauty and Goodne≈øs; and adds, The more you come downward towards that Part called the Slave Coa≈øt (I ≈øuppo≈øe becau≈øe the mo≈øt Slaves are brought from thence) the more delightful and rich the Sol appears.

Barbot ≈øays, The Inland People employ them≈øelves in Tillage and Trade, and ≈øupply the Markets with Corn, Fruit and Palm Wine; the Country producing ≈øuch va≈øt Plenty of Indian Wheat, that Abundance is daily exported,
as well by Europeans as Blacks, re≈øorting thither from other Parts. He adds, That the Country of Delmina, which was formerly very powerful and populous, though now ≈øo much drained of its Inhabitants, by the inte≈øtine Wars fomented among≈øt the Negroes by the Dutch, that there does not remain enough Inhabitants to till the Country; abounded with fine well-built and populous Towns, enriched with va≈øt Fields of Corn, Cattle, Palm Wine and Oil. The Inhabitants all applying them≈øelves, without Di≈øtinction, to Agriculture, ≈øowing Corn, pre≈ø≈øing Oil, and drawing Wine from Palm Trees, with both of which it is plentifully ≈øtored others to fi≈øhing, and boiling Salt, and other Trades, on their own Account, or as Brokers for the Inland Blacks.

Many more Accounts could be given of the good Di≈øpo≈øition of the Generality of the Negroes, and of the Plenty their Coutry affords, in which it, perhaps, exceeds mo≈øt Countries in the World; but this is ≈øufficient to ≈øhew that they might have lived happily, more e≈øpecially if the Europeans had not only bore the Name, but had acted the Part of Chri≈øtians, in u≈øing their Endeavour, by Example as well as Precept, to make the Negroes acquainted with the glad Tidings of the Go≈øpel, and with that Change of Heart, and Redemption from Sin, which Chri≈øtianity prorpo≈øes; this, if attended to, would have nece≈ø≈øarily been productive of the peaceable Fruits of Righteou≈øne≈øs; Innocency and Love
would have prevailed, and nothing would have been wanting to compleat the≈øe poor Africans Happine≈øs. But the Rever≈øe has happened; the Europeans, forgetful of their Profe≈ø≈øion and Duty as Men and Chri≈øtians, have conducted in ≈øo iniquitous a Manner, as mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily rai≈øe in the Minds of the thoughtful and well-di≈øpo≈øed Negroes the utmo≈øt Scorn and Dete≈øtation of the very Name of Chri≈øtians. They have made all other Con≈øiderations give Way to an in≈øatiable De≈øire of Gain, and are become the principal and moving Cau≈øe of the mo≈øt iniquitous and dreadful Scene that was, perhaps, ever acted upon this Globe: In≈øtead of making u≈øe of their ≈øuperior Knowledge to ≈øtir up the Principle of Peace and Good-will in the Brea≈øts of the ≈øimple unwary Negroes, they have acted as Agents for the great Enemy of the Happine≈øs of Mankind, and have ≈øtirred up and ≈øtrengthened the earthly Principle of Craft and Covetou≈øne≈øs in the poor Africans, who have thereby been induced to captivate and ≈øell their unhappy Countrymen; every Thing, even the Power of their Kings, has been made ≈øub≈øervient to an≈øwer this wicked Purpo≈øe; in≈øtead of being Protectors of their Subjects, the≈øe Rulers, allured by the tempting Baits laid before them by the Factors, &c. have invaded the Liberties of their unhappy Subjects, and are become their Oppre≈ø≈øors; as is fully evidenced by the following Account, viz.

Francis Moore, Factor to the african Company in 1730, tells his Reader, That when the King of Bar≈øalli wants Goods or Brandy, he
≈øends a Me≈ø≈øenger to the Engli≈øh Governor at James's Fort, to de≈øire he would ≈øend up a Sloop with a Cargoe of Goods, which, ≈øays the Author, the Governor never fails to do: Again≈øt the Time the Ve≈ø≈øel arrives, the King plunders ≈øome of his Enemies Towns, ≈øelling the People for ≈øuch Goods as he wants, which commonly is Brandy or Rum, Gunpowder, Ball, Fire-arms, Pi≈øtols and Cutla≈ø≈øes for his Soldiers, &c. and Coral and Silver for his Wives and Mi≈øtre≈ø≈øes.‚ÄîIf he is at War with no neighbouring King, he falls upon one of his own Towns, and makes bold to ≈øell his own mi≈øerable Subjects. He often goes with ≈øome of his Troops by a Town in the Day-time, and returns in the Night, and ≈øets Fire to three Parts of it, placing Guards at the Fourth, to ≈øeize the People that run out of the Fire, then ties their Arms behind them, and marches them to Joar or Rohone, where he ≈øells them.

Brue, the French Factor bef√≥re-mentioned, ≈øays, That having received Goods, he wrote to the King, that if he had a ≈øufficient Number of Slaves, he was ready to trade with him, this Prince, ≈øays that Author, as well as the other Negroe Monarchs, have always a ≈øure Way of ≈øupplying his Deficiencies, by ≈øelling their own Subjects, for which they ≈øeldom want Preten≈øions of ≈øome Kind or other, to ju≈øtify their Rapine. The≈øe Negroe Kings, thus ≈øeeking Pretences to cover their Crimes, ≈øhews they are not quite void of Shame, and in≈øen≈øible that Covetou≈øne≈øs induces them to act a
Part ≈øo incon≈øi≈øtent with their Duty; but here they may plead the Example and Solicitation of the more knowing Europeans. The King had Recour≈øe to this Method, by ≈øeizing Three Hundred of his own People, and ≈øent Word to Brue, that he had the Slaves ready to deliver for the Goods. The ≈øame Author further adds, That ≈øome of the Natives are, on all Occa≈øions, endeavouring to ≈øurprize and carry off their Country People; they land (≈øays he) without Noi≈øe, and if they find any lone Cottage, without Defence, they ≈øurround it, and carry off all the People and Effects to their Boat: The Slaves are ≈øold to the Europeans, unle≈øs they be Per≈øons of ≈øome Rank, who≈øe Friends can redeem them, by paying two Slaves, or five or ≈øix Oxen.

John Barbot ≈øays, The Slaves ≈øold by the Negroes are for the mo≈øt Part Pri≈øoners of War, or taken in the Incur≈øions they make into their Enemies Territories; others are ≈øtolen away by their own Countrymen. Abundance of little Blacks, of both Sexes, are ≈øtolen away by their Neighbours, when found abroad, on the Roads, or in the Woods, or el≈øe in the Corn Fields, at the Time of the Year when their Parents keep them there all Day, to ≈øcare away the devouring ≈ømall Birds.

Francis Moore, the Engli≈øh Factor, ≈øays, That captivating the People is, by Cu≈øtom, become ≈øo familiar, that when the King of Kayor wants to make a Pre≈øent to the Factor, for what he has received of him, he ≈øends to have two or
three Slaves taken up at the neare≈øt Village. Unhappy (≈øays that Author) are they, who at that Time fall into the Hands of his Guards, for they ≈øtay to make no Choice. And he further ≈øays, That in Battle they ≈øpare the Enemies as much as po≈ø≈øible, but it is only that they may have the more Slaves; from which even Per≈øons of Quality, taken Pri≈øoners, are not exempted: That the Merchants bring down ≈øome Years, to that Factory, to the Amount of Two Thou≈øand Slaves; which, they ≈øay, are taken Pri≈øoners in War: The≈øe they buy from the different Princes who take them; many of them come from a great Way In-land. Their Way of bringing them, is tying them by the Neck with Leather Thongs, at about a Yard Di≈øtance from each other, having generally a Bundle of Corn, or Elephants Teeth, on each of their Heads, Thirty or Forty in a String. The Author judges, That the Number of Merchants who followed this Trade were about an Hundred. Some Authors ≈øay, They go Six or Seven Hundred Miles up the Country, with Goods bought from the Engli≈øh, with which they purcha≈øe the≈øe Slaves, and Ivory: Be≈øides tho≈øe Slaves, there are many bought along the River; the≈øe are either taken in War, as the former, or Men condemned for Crimes, or Per≈øons ≈øtolen, which is very frequently. Since the Slave Trade has been introduced, all Puni≈øhments are commuted in this; and they ≈øtrain hard for Crimes, in order to have the Benefit of ≈øelling
the Criminal; ≈øo that not only great Crimes but even trifling ones, are at pre≈øent puni≈øhed with Slavery.

Bo≈øman ≈øays, That being in the Kingdom of Pope, who depend on Plunder and the Slaves Trade, in which they exceed ≈øome of their Neighbours, becau≈øe, being endued with a much larger Share of Courage, they rob more ≈øucce≈øsfully, they a≈ø≈øured him, that if he would have Patience for three Days, they would be able to deliver him One or Two Hundred Slaves, and that their Incur≈øions ≈øucceeded ≈øo well, they returned with about Two Hundred Slaves. That the Inhabitants of Arda were ≈øo diligent in the Slave Trade, that they were able to deliver a Thou≈øand Slaves every Month; and that if there happened to be no Stock of Slaves when the Ve≈ø≈øels arrived, they would ≈øometimes ≈øend their Commodities Two Hundred Miles deep in the Country (a later Author ≈øays, they have now carried the Trade Five Hundred Miles farther, going now Seven Hundred Miles back into the Country) where Markets of Men were kept in the ≈øame Manner as tho≈øe of Bea≈øts with us. Mo≈øt of the Slaves are Pri≈øoners of War, which are ≈øold by the Victors as their Booty. When the≈øe Slaves come to Fida, they are put in Pri≈øon altogether; and when (≈øays he) we treat concerning baying them, they are all brought out together in a large Plain, where, by our Surgeons, they are thoroughly examined, and that naked too, both Men and Women, without the lea≈øt Di≈øtinction or Mode≈øty. Tho≈øe which are approved
as good, are ≈øet on one Side; in the mean while a burning Iron, with the Arms or Name of the Companies, lies in the Fire, with which ours are marked on the Brea≈øt. When we have agreed with the Owners of the Slaves, they are returned to their Pri≈øons, where, from that Time forward, they are kept at our Charge, co≈øt us Two-pence a Day a Slave, which ≈øerves to ≈øub≈øi≈øt them like our Criminals on Bread and Water; ≈øo that, to ≈øave Charges, we ≈øend them on board our Ships with the very fir≈øt Opportunity; before which, their Ma≈øters ≈øtrip the ‚Ä¢ of all they have on their Backs, ≈øo that they come on board ≈øtark naked, as well Women as Men: In which Condition they are obliged to continue, if the Ma≈øter of the Ship is not ≈øo charitable (which he commonly is) as to be≈øtow ≈øomething on them to cover their Nakedne≈øs.‚ÄîSix or Seven Hundred are ≈øometimes put on board a Ve≈ø≈øel, where they lie as clo≈øe together as po≈ø≈øible for them to be crouded.‚ÄîI doubt not, ≈øays the ≈øame Author, but this Trade ≈øeems very barbarous to you, but, ≈øince it is followed by meer Nece≈ø≈øity, it mu≈øt go on. What Nece≈ø≈øity does the Author mean, no other Nece≈ø≈øity appears but that ari≈øing from the De≈øire of ama≈ø≈øing Riches; a Nece≈ø≈øity laid on worldly Men by their hard Ta≈øk-ma≈øter the Devil? Many more Examples might be given to ≈øhew the arbitrary and tyrannick Oppre≈ø≈øion with which this Trade is carried on, and the Deva≈øtation and Blood≈øhed it occa≈øions in tho≈øe unhappy People's Country; but I tru≈øt this is ≈øufficient to convince the candid, con≈øiderate Reader of the
Unlawfulne≈øs and Iniquity of the Trade. And indeed what Di≈øtre≈øs can we conceive equal to the Alarms, the Anxiety and Wrath, which mu≈øt ≈øucceed one another in the Brea≈øts of the tender Parents, or affectionate Children, in continual Danger of being torn one from another, and dragged into a State of cruel Bondage; Reader, if the Impre≈ø≈øions of Grace, or even the common Feelings of Humanity, are not ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed in thy Heart by the Love of Gain, compare what thou ha≈øt read with the Equity, the Sympathy, the Tenderne≈øs and affectionate Love which is the Life of Chri≈øtianity, and then ≈øay, what Concord or Affinity can the≈øe Fruits have one with the other. May not this Trade be truly ≈øaid to be the mo≈øt iniquitous and cruele≈øt Act of Violence and Rapine, when con≈øidered in all its Circum≈øtances, that, to our Knowledge, is perpetrated in any Part of the World, and that therefore it behoves every one who is de≈øirous to maintain the Te≈øtimony of a good Con≈øcience, and enjoy Re≈øt and Peace in Time and Eternity, to avoid being, in any Re≈øpect, defiled by the Gain re≈øulting therefrom. And Thanks be to the Great Father of the Family of the whole Earth, that it is not alone in America that ≈øome are rai≈øed to bear their Te≈øtimony again≈øt this mighty Evil, but that a noble Indignation is al≈øo rai≈øed in the Brea≈øts of ≈øome in our Mother Country, zealou≈øly to declare again≈øt ≈øo unparalelled Inva≈øion upon the Rights and Liberties of Mankind, particularly George Wallis, a Gentleman of the Law, in a Book wrote by him, intituled, A Sy≈øtem
of the Principles of the Law of Scotland; in which, ≈øpeaking of the Slavery of the Negroes in our Colonies, he ≈øays; "We all know that they (the Negroes) are purcha≈øed from their Princes, who pretend to have a Right to di≈øpo≈øe of them, and that they are, like other Commodities, tran≈øported by the Merchants, who have bought them, into America, in order to be expo≈øed to Sale. If this Trade admits of a moral or a rational Ju≈øtification, every Crime, even the mo≈øt atrocious, may be ju≈øtified. Government was in≈øtituted for the Good of Mankind; Kings, Princes, Governors, are not Proprietors of tho≈øe who are ≈øubject to their Authority; they have not a Right to make them mi≈øerable. On the contrary, their Authority is ve≈øted in them, that they may, by the ju≈øt Exerci≈øe of it, promote the Happine≈øs of their People. Of Cour≈øe, they they have not a Right to di≈øpo≈øe of their Liberty, and to ≈øell them for Slaves. Be≈øides, no Man has a Right to acquire or to purcha≈øe them; Men and their Liberty are not (in Commercio) they are not either ≈øaleable or purcha≈øeable. One, therefore, has no body but him≈øelf to blame, in ca≈øe he ≈øhall find him≈øelf deprived of a Man, whom he thought he had, by buying for a Price, made his own; for he dealt in a Trade which was illicit, and was prohibited by the mo≈øt obvious Dictates of Humanity. For the≈øe Rea≈øons every one of tho≈øe unfortunate Men, who are pretended to be Slaves, has a Right to be declared to be free,
for he never lo≈øt his Liberty; he could not lo≈øe it; his Prince had no Power to di≈øpo≈øe of him. Of Cour≈øe the Sale was ip≈øo Jure void. This Right he carries about with him, and is entitled every where to get it declared. As ≈øoon, therefore, as he comes into a Country in which the Judges are not forgetful of their own Humanity, it is their Duty to remember that he is a Man, and to declare him to be free. I know it has been ≈øaid, that Que≈øtions concerning the State of Per≈øons ought to be determined by the Law of the Country to which they belong; and that, therefore, one who would be declared to be a Slave in America, ought, in ca≈øe he ≈øhould happen to be imported into Britain, to be adjudged according to the Law of America to be a Slave; a Doctrine than which nothing can be more barbarous. Ought the Judges of any Country, out of Re≈øpect to the Law of another, to ≈øhew no Re≈øpect to their Kind, and to Humanity. Out of Re≈øpect to a Law, which is in no Sort obligatory upon them, ought they to di≈øregard the Law of Nature, which is obligatory on all Men at all Times, and in all Places: Are any Laws ≈øo binding as the eternal Laws of Ju≈øtice? Is it doubtful, whether a Judge ought to pay greater Regard to them, than to tho≈øe arbitrary and inhuman U≈øages which prevail in a di≈øtant Land? Aye, but our Colonies would be ruined, if Slavery was aboli≈øhed. Be it ≈øo; would it not from thence follow, that the Bulk of Mankind ought to be
abu≈øed, that our Pockets may be filled with Money, or our Mouths with Delicacies? The Pur≈øes of Highwaymen would be empty in ca≈øe Robberies were totally aboli≈øhed; but have Men a Right to acquire Money by going out to the Highway? Have Men a Right to acquire it by rendering their Fellow Creatures mi≈øerable? Is it lawful to abu≈øe Mankind, that the Avarice, the Vanity, or the Pa≈ø≈øions of a few may be gratified? No! there is ≈øuch a Thing as Ju≈øtice, to which the mo≈øt ≈øacred Regard is due. It ought to be inviolably ob≈øerved. Have not the≈øe unhappy Men a better Right to their Liberty, and to their Happine≈øs, than our American Merchants have to the Profits which they make by torturing their Kind? Let therefore our Colonies be ruined, but let us not render ≈øo many Men mi≈øerable. Would not any of us, who ≈øhould‚Äîbe ≈ønatched by Pyrates from his native Land, think him≈øelf cruelly abu≈øed, and at all Times intitled to be free. Have not the≈øe unfortunate Africans, who meet with the ≈øame cruel Fate, the ≈øame Right? Are not they Men as well as we, and have they not the ≈øame Sen≈øibility? Let us not, therefore, defend or ≈øupport a U≈øage which is contrary to all the Laws of Humanity.

But it is fal≈øe, that either we or our Colonies would be ruined by the Abolition of Slavery. It might occa≈øion a Stagnation of Bu≈øine≈øs for a ≈øhort Time. Every great Alteration produces that Effect; becau≈øe Mankind cannot, on a ≈øudden, find Ways of di≈øpo≈øing of them≈øelves,
and of their Affairs: But it would produce many happy Effects. It is the Slavery which is permitted in America that has hindered it from becoming ≈øo ≈øoon populous, as it would otherwi≈øe have done. Let the Negroes free, and, in a few Generations, this va≈øt and fertile Continent would be crowded with Inhabitants; Learning, Arts, and every Thing would flouri≈øh among≈øt them; in≈øtead of being inhabited by wild Bea≈øts, and by Savages, it would be peopled by Philo≈øophers, and by Men."‚Äî Thus far this hone≈øt and noble ≈øpirited Briton.

And now Reader, if from the Example of others, and without a ≈øufficient Knowledge of the deplorable Con≈øequences attendant on this Trade, thou ha≈øt inadvertently engaged therein, let me be≈øeech thee, by the Mercies of CHRIST JESUS our LORD (tho≈øe Mercies which, perhaps, e'er long, thou and I ≈øhall de≈øire to fly to as our only Refuge) that thou would≈øt refrain a Practice ≈øo incon≈øi≈øtent with thy Duty, both as a Chri≈øtian and a Man. Remember, the fir≈øt and chief Commandment is, Thou ≈øhalt love the Lord thy God with all thy Heart. And that the Second like unto it is, Thou ≈øhalt love thy Neighbour as thy≈øelf. That our ble≈ø≈øed Redeemer has enjoined us to do unto others as we would they ≈øhould do unto us; and that it will be tho≈øe who have been righteous and merciful to their Fellow Creatures, that will be intitled to the Mercy of the Great Judge of Heaven and Earth, before whom we mu≈øt all appear, to give an Account of the Deeds done in the Body.

And as for tho≈øe who confe≈øs them≈øelves now, convinced of the Iniquity of this Trade, and the Inju≈øtice of buying and ≈øelling their Fellow Creatures, and yet continue to keep tho≈øe Negroes they are po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of in Bondage, for the Sake of the Profit ari≈øing from their Labour, it behoves them ≈øeriou≈øly to con≈øider their Motives for ≈øuch a Conduct; whether the Di≈øtinction they make between buying a Negroe, and keeping the ≈øame Negroe, or his Offspring, in perpetual Bondage, is not a Plea founded more in Words than ≈øupported by Truth; for it mu≈øt be obvious to every Per≈øon, who is not blinded by the De≈øire of Gain, that the Right by which the≈øe Men hold the Negroes in Bondage, is no other than what is derived from tho≈øe who ≈øtole them, or received them from the Thief, who having no other Title, but that which Robbers have over their Prey, could not convey any better to the Purcha≈øer; and that therefore to continue to hold them in Bondage, for worldly Advantage, by no other Right than that which tho≈øe guilty Men gave them, is con≈øenting to, and partaking of their Guilt. In≈øtances may fall out, where Men of Candour may be concerned in the Purcha≈øe of Negroes, purely from a Principle of Charity; and there are al≈øo many of the Blacks, among≈øt us, who≈øe Di≈øpo≈øtions, Infirmities or Age, render them unfit for Freedom; but in the Ca≈øe beforementioned, where Per≈øons declare them≈øelves convinced of the Inju≈øtice and Iniquity of this Trade, and are po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of Negroes who are capable of managing for them≈øelves, and have ≈øufficiently
paid, by their Labour, for their Purcha≈øe or bringing up, be≈øides the Profit ≈øome Families have reaped, during a long Cour≈øe of Years, from the Labour of their Progenitors; it is the undoubted Duty of their Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øors to re≈øtore to them that Liberty, of which they, or their Parents, have been unju≈øtly deprived; and they ought al≈øo to u≈øe all rea≈øonable Endeavours, to enable them to procure a comfortable Living, not only as an Act of Ju≈øtice to the Individuals, but as a Debt due to them, on Account of the Oppre≈ø≈øion and Inju≈øtice perpetrated on them, or their Ance≈øtors; and as the be≈øt Means in their Power, to avert the Judgments of GOD, which it is to be feared will fall on Families and Countries, in Proportion as they have, more or le≈øs, defiled them≈øelves with this iniquitous Traffick.

div.head: EXTRACTS from a Manu≈øcript, intituled, Two Dialogues on the MAN-TRADE.
Printed in London, in the Year 1760.
div.p:
THE African Blacks are as properly and truly Men, as the European Whites; they are both of the ≈øame Species, and are originally de≈øcended from the ≈øame Parents;‚Äîthey have the ≈øame rational Powers as we have; they have free moral Agents, as we are, and many of them have as good natural Genius, as good and as brave a Spirit, as any of tho≈øe to whom they are made
Slaves. To trade in Blacks, then, is to trade in Men; the black-≈økin'd and the white-≈økin'd being all of the ≈øame Species, all of the human Race, are by Nature upon an Equality; one Man in a State of Nature, as we are with Re≈øpect to the Inhabitants of Guiney, and they with Re≈øpect to us, is not ≈øuperior to another Man, nor has any Authority or Dominion over him, or any Right to lay his Commands upon him: He that made us, made them, and all of the ≈øame Clay: We are all the Workman≈øhip of his Hands, and he hath a≈ø≈øigned this Globe to the human Race, to dwell upon: He hath given this Earth, in common, to the Children of Men.‚ÄîGOD gave to Man Dominion over the Fi≈øh of the Sea, and over the Fowl of the Air, and over the Cattle, and over all the Earth, and over every creeping Thing that creepeth upon the Earth, Gen. i. 26; but not to any one Man over another: Nor can one Man, on any Suppo≈øition whatever, become the Property, or Part of the Goods or E≈øtate, of another Man; as his Hor≈øe or his Dog is.

The European Whites, and the African Blacks, are all under the ≈øame Moral Law, the eternal Law of Rea≈øon, which GOD hath written upon the Table of Man's Heart. We and they are Members of one and the ≈øame great Society, ≈øpread over the Face of the whole Earth, under one and the ≈øame Supreme Law-giver and Judge; and are joined together, by the clo≈øe and ≈øtrong Ties of human Nature, common to us all; and it is in this Bond of Humanity, that is the Foundation of all other particular Ties and Connections
between Men, and gives Strength to them all. ‚ÄîA Patriot, or a Lover of his Country, is a brave Character; but a Lover of Mankind is a braver Character.

Our being Chri≈øtians does not give us any worldly Superiority, or any Authority whatever, over tho≈øe who are not Chri≈øtians. CHRIST'S Kingdom is not of this World; neither does Chri≈øtianity di≈ø≈øolve or free us from the Obligations of Ju≈øtice, Equity, and Benevolence towards our Fellow Creatures of the ≈øame Species, be they Jews, Mahometans, or even black-≈økin'd Heathens, which the Law of Nature lays us under; but, on the contrary, greatly ≈øtrengthens them. The Jews, in our Saviour's Time, under≈øtood that Precept, Thou ≈øhalt love thy Neighbour as thy≈øelf, in a very confined Sen≈øe, as relating only to their own Countrymen. But this Precept, as adopted into the Chri≈øtian Religion, takes in all Mankind. By our Neighbour we are to under≈øtand every Individual of the human Species. We are commanded in the Go≈øpel; to render all their Dues, and to do unto others, as we would they ≈øhould do unto us, to be kind, merciful and compa≈ø≈øionate, to be ready to communicate, and to do Good. Which Precept, and many others to the ≈øame Purpo≈øe, are not to be under≈øtood, in ≈øuch a narrow Sen≈øe, as if they related only to tho≈øe who are of the ≈øame Religion with our≈øelves, or who≈øe Skin is of the ≈øame Colour with ours, as is evident from other Precepts of the Go≈øpel. We are commanded to do Good to all, e≈øpecially to tho≈øe who are of the Hou≈øhold of
Faith, to imitate our Heavenly Father, who doeth Good to all, and who≈øe tender Mercies are over all his Works, yea, and to love our Enemies. ‚ÄîThe≈øe Propo≈øitions I believe no body would have refu≈øed to grant; but though they are ≈øo evident that few will expre≈øly deny, or di≈øpute the Truth of them, yet, it is rea≈øonable to ≈øuppo≈øe, that tho≈øe who are concerned in the Man-Trade, do not allow them≈øelves to think on the≈øe Truths impartially, ≈øeriou≈øly to con≈øider them, and lay them to Heart; but that on the contrary, they have, ≈øome how or other, a Kind of confu≈øed Imagination, or half formed Thought, in their Minds, that the Blacks are hardly of the ≈øame Species with the white Men, but are Creatures of a Kind ≈øomewhat inferior: I ≈øay it is rea≈øonable to ≈øuppo≈øe ≈øo; for I do not know how to think that any white Men could find in their Hearts, that the common Sentiments of Humanity would permit them to treat the black Men in that cruel, barbarous Manner in which they do treat them, did they think and con≈øider that the≈øe have rational immortal Souls, that they are made after the Image of GOD, as well as them≈øelves, and that, being in the ≈øame Body, they have the ≈øame Pa≈ø≈øions, Sen≈øes and Feelings, as they have, and are as ≈øu≈øceptible of Pain and Grief, and upon the ≈øame Occa≈øions, as they.‚ÄîMan-≈øtealing is not only unlawful‚ÄîI think it the mo≈øt atrocious, dete≈øtate Crime. To ≈øteal a Hor≈øe, or to rob a Man on the Road of his Money, is reckoned, among us, a capital Crime, de≈øerving Death and is, by Law, puni≈øhable with Death. What then
does he de≈øerve, what Puni≈øhment can be great enough for him, who ≈øteals a Man, a Crime, in Compari≈øon with which Hor≈øe-≈øtealing or robbing on the Highway is but a little trifling Fault, quite excu≈øeable and venial. Man-≈øtealers were, by the Law of Mo≈øes, puni≈øhed with Death. He that ≈øtealeth a Man, or if he be found in his Hand, he ≈øhall ≈øurely be put to Death, Exod. xxi. 16.
